description: Regular verbs ending in -ar conjugated in the present tense: -o, -as, -a, -amos, -áis, -an. Used for habitual actions, general truths, and current states.
common_errors: Forgetting to drop the -ar before adding endings
Confusing -as (tú) with -a (él/ella)

description: Regular verbs ending in -er conjugated in the present tense: -o, -es, -e, -emos, -éis, -en.
common_errors: Mixing up -er and -ir endings
Forgetting the accent on some forms

description: Regular verbs ending in -ir conjugated in the present tense: -o, -es, -e, -imos, -ís, -en. Note: -er and -ir share most endings except nosotros and vosotros.
common_errors: Confusing -ir endings with -er endings in nosotros/vosotros forms

description: Ser for permanent characteristics (nationality, profession, personality, origin, time, material). Estar for temporary states (emotions, locations, conditions, weather feelings). Both mean 'to be' but are not interchangeable.
common_errors: Using ser for location (should be estar)
Using estar for nationality (should be ser)
Confusing 'soy aburrido' (I'm boring) with 'estoy aburrido' (I'm bored)

description: Tener is irregular: tengo, tienes, tiene, tenemos, tenéis, tienen. Also used in expressions: tener hambre, tener sed, tener frío, tener calor, tener miedo, tener sueño, tener X años.
common_errors: Saying 'soy X años' instead of 'tengo X años'
Forgetting go-ending in yo form: tengo

description: Ir is highly irregular: voy, vas, va, vamos, vais, van. Always followed by 'a' + destination or infinitive (ir a + infinitive = near future).
common_errors: Forgetting 'a' after ir
Confusing ir with irse (to leave)

description: Hacer is irregular: hago, haces, hace, hacemos, hacéis, hacen. Also used for weather: hace calor, hace frío, hace sol, hace viento.
common_errors: Forgetting the irregular yo form 'hago'
Using ser/estar for weather instead of hacer

description: Nouns in Spanish are masculine or feminine. Adjectives must agree in gender and number with the noun they modify. General rules: -o = masculine, -a = feminine. Plurals: add -s after vowel, -es after consonant.
common_errors: Using masculine adjective with feminine noun
Forgetting to make adjective plural
Exceptions like 'el problema' (masculine despite -a ending)

description: Definite: el, la, los, las (the). Indefinite: un, una, unos, unas (a/an/some). Articles must agree in gender and number with their noun. Use 'el' before feminine nouns starting with stressed 'a': el agua, el águila.
common_errors: Confusing el/la with masculine/feminine nouns
Overusing articles (Spanish uses them more than English in some cases)

description: Questions can be formed by: 1) Inversion: ¿Hablas español? 2) Question words: ¿Qué?, ¿Quién?, ¿Dónde?, ¿Cuándo?, ¿Cómo?, ¿Por qué?, ¿Cuánto?, ¿Cuál? All questions use ¿...? punctuation.
common_errors: Forgetting the opening question mark ¿
Wrong question word (cuál vs qué)
Incorrect inversion after question words

description: Place 'no' directly before the conjugated verb to make a sentence negative. Double negatives are standard in Spanish: No tengo nada, No voy nunca, No conozco a nadie.
common_errors: Placing no after the verb
Avoiding double negatives (they're correct in Spanish)

description: Gustar literally means 'to please'. Structure: indirect object pronoun + gusta/gustan + subject. Me gusta el café (Coffee pleases me = I like coffee). Use gusta + singular/infinitive, gustan + plural.
common_errors: Saying 'yo gusto' instead of 'me gusta'
Using gusta with plural nouns (should be gustan)

description: Unstressed possessives before the noun: mi(s), tu(s), su(s), nuestro/a(s), vuestro/a(s), su(s). They agree in number with the thing possessed, not the possessor. Nuestro/vuestro also agree in gender.
common_errors: Confusing su (his/her/your formal/their)
Forgetting plural -s: 'mis libros' not 'mi libros'

description: Estar + gerund (-ando for -ar verbs, -iendo for -er/-ir verbs) for actions in progress right now. Estoy hablando = I am speaking. Irregular gerunds: durmiendo, leyendo, diciendo.
common_errors: Using present progressive for habitual actions (use simple present instead)
Irregular gerund forms: leyendo not leiendo

description: Express future plans using ir + a + infinitive. Voy a estudiar = I'm going to study. This is the most common way to express future at A1 level.
common_errors: Forgetting the 'a' between ir and the infinitive
Conjugating both verbs (only ir is conjugated)
